p: Jaundice may be a practical method for conducting viral hepatitis surveillance in areas where laboratory testing is not routinely included in healthcare visits. For example, in a surveillance system developed to measure the frequency of hepatitis E in northern Uganda, epidemiologists implemented a system originally designed for malaria surveillance [ 83]. Upon presentation of a person with jaundice to one of the facilities where providers were trained, providers completed a brief case report form, and collected a specimen that was then sent to a central laboratory [ 83]. At a centralized location, the information from the case report forms and the laboratory results were processed and analyzed to determine the frequency of the different etiologies of jaundice [ 83].
